question_text: What role does powder morphology and porosity play in enhancing shock-induced reactions in Ni-Al systems, and how do these factors influence reaction yield and initiation mechanisms?
standard_answer: Powder morphology and porosity critically enhance shock-induced reactions by optimizing contact surface area, plastic deformation, and hot spot formation. Flake Ni powders (~0.3 mm thick) or fine spherical particles (~1 μm) provide higher surface area and thinner diffusion scales compared to coarse spherical powders, leading to increased reaction yields. For instance, flake Ni with coarse Al achieves complete conversion, whereas spherical Ni with coarse Al reacts only partially. Porosity (void volume) facilitates reaction by allowing greater plastic flow and pore collapse during shock compression. Higher porosity (e.g., >50% TMD) promotes turbulent particle flow, cleansing surfaces, introducing defects, and generating localized temperatures through visco-plastic heating. This enhances mass mixing and reduces ignition thresholds. Conversely, low porosity (<40% TMD) retards reactions due to reduced deformation and higher thermal diffusivity, which dissipates heat more efficiently. The CONMAH model conceptualizes this, where configuration, mixing, activation, and heating in the transition zone during shock compression drive synthesis. Thus, tailored morphology and porosity maximize mechanical activation, enabling reactions at lower shock parameters by improving interparticle contact and energy localization.

original_text.1: It was shown that reaction yield strongly depends on the morphology of the particles used. For example, mixture 4 with flake Ni (45 μm in width) and coarse spherical Al (45 μm) possessed the complete reaction yield, in contrast to the spherical Ni (45 μm) and coarse spherical Al (45 μm), which reacted only partially.
original_text.2: The porosity of the initial media: absence of voids retards the reaction. For example, it was shown that for flake Ni-Spherical Al powder mixture, only traces of the Ni3Al phase were observed when the initial porosity of the media was below 40%, and complete conversion was achieved with porosity above 50%.
